Sure, here are some ways that Cyril Ramaphosa's government has tackled corruption in South Africa:

1. Appointment of a new head of the National Prosecuting Authority (NPA): The NPA is the organization responsible for prosecuting corruption cases in South Africa. In 2018, Ramaphosa appointed a new head of the NPA, Shamila Batohi, who has pledged to tackle corruption and prosecute those responsible for it.

2. Establishment of a Commission of Inquiry into State Capture: In 2018, Ramaphosa established the Commission of Inquiry into State Capture, which is investigating allegations of corruption and state capture during the tenure of former President Jacob Zuma. The commission has been given extensive powers and has been able to uncover evidence of corruption and wrongdoing.

3. Strengthening of anti-corruption agencies: Ramaphosa's government has prioritized strengthening the capabilities of anti-corruption agencies, such as the Special Investigating Unit and the Hawks, to enable them to tackle corruption more effectively.

4. Implementation of lifestyle audits: Ramaphosa has introduced measures to carry out lifestyle audits on government officials and public servants, in order to identify unexplained wealth and potential conflicts of interest.

5. Prosecution of corrupt officials: Under Ramaphosa's leadership, several high-profile government officials and business people have been prosecuted for corruption, including former President Jacob Zuma.

Overall, Ramaphosa's government has taken several significant steps to tackle corruption in South Africa, which has helped to rebuild trust in government institutions and promote investment in the country.
